awd_titl_txt: CRII: CHS: Investigating Multilingual Teams Communication and Collaborative Writing
awd_abstract_narration:
In multilingual teams, people speaking different native languages combine expertise and perspectives to achieve common goals. A major problem faced by multilingual teams involves grounding--establishing shared understanding of intended meanings--during collaborative writing in English. Common ways to establish grounding such as face-to-face chat create additional challenges, such as the need for verbal explanations and overlapping schedules. This project investigates new ways to create grounding in multilingual teams engaged in collaborative writing. It will improve understanding and develop new tools. Knowledge and design solutions generated from this project will benefit diverse workers, including members of global research projects, students in international education programs, and employees of multinational business organizations.

The project introduces the term “editing traces” to refer to information generated as a by-product of document editing processes. Editing traces will be investigated as a means of grounding communication in a collaborative writing environment. Sharing selective editing traces between native speakers (NS) and non-native speakers (NNS) will be researched as a means for grounding intended meanings. Three interwoven activities are expected to contribute to developing new understandings of practices, needs and requirements involving conversational grounding in collaborative writing activities, and techniques for supporting them: (1) developing classifications of grounding issues and editing traces for understanding how collaborative writing works in multilingual teams; (2) specifying the effects of using selectively displayed editing traces from NNS to alleviate targeted grounding problems detected by NS; and (3) using editing traces in the design of a tool that supports the establishment of grounding between NS and NNS.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Modern collaborative work often involves individuals who speak different native languages. One significant roadblock to the success of work communication and performance is the imbalance in common language (e.g., English) fluency among collaborators. Our research project aimed to pinpoint the connections between written communication performed at different stages of the multilingual teamwork. In particular, we hypothesized that certain actions occurring in an earlier stage of the teamwork would provide hints for smoothing the work communication in later stages. We planned to identify such hints through a series of empirical studies, then leverage the insights gained from these studies to design systems that can enhance multilingual teamwork. 


Over the course of this project, we studied how multilingual teams conduct written communication under two representative scenarios. One scenario involves native and non-native English speakers participating in remote work discussions through the exchange of instant messages (IM; e.g., Slack messaging). The other scenario involved native and non-native English speakers collaborating on document editing via online writing platforms (e.g., Google Docs). Behavioral data gathered from these research activities supported our idea of enhancing written communication in a given stage of multilingual teamwork (i.e., an online discussion or a document editing session) with hints extracted from earlier stages of the teamwork. 


For IM-based online discussions, our work has revealed that written communication in multilingual teams features a two-step workflow. People often exchange ideas in subgroups where everyone shares the same native language. These exchanges prepare them for team-level discussions at a later point and in English as the work language. Through a series of lab experiments, we demonstrated that the cognitive context extracted from subgroup conversations could effectively enhance the clarity and in-depth of team-level discussions occurring afterward. More importantly, we applied conversation analysis to pinpoint selected types of information that are essential for retrieving this cognitive context. We also leveraged computational techniques to enable the automated extraction of each type of information. This work has resulted in a set of publications at top-tier human-computer interaction (HCI), computer-supported cooperative work (CSCW), and natural language processing (NLP) venues. 


For online document editing, our work has found that written communication in multilingual teams features a late-mover disadvantage toward the non-native speakers. This finding is backed by our collection and analysis of longitudinal data on collaborative writing between native and non-native English speakers. We applied sequential analysis to identify the connection between writing actions performed by co-writers of the same team but at successive editing turns. This analysis showed that a non-native speaker's contribution to the ideation aspect of the document could be suppressed by certain types of edits made by their co-writers who are native speakers, but not the other way around. Furthermore, our analysis of the co-writers' interactions with AI-powered editing tools challenged the prevailing view of such tools as unequivocal "productivity boosters" for non-native speaker. Based on the above findings, we developed algorithms and visualization tools to help people identify the sequential patterns of their co-writing behaviors and make fair interpretations of each person's contribution to the teamwork. This work has generated a series of papers submitted to top-tier CSCW and visualization/design venues. 


Intellectual merit: This project has generated new theories and understandings of written communication in multilingual teams, which contributes novel knowledge to HCI, CSCW, NLP, and Human-Centered AI research. It has also developed a set of in-house language processing algorithms, clustering algorithms, and visualization systems that can be adopted by future research, as well as practice, in the space of multilingual teamwork and human-AI coordination. Findings concluded from this research offer a benchmark for testing the effects of future behavioral interventions and technical solutions that aim to improve IM-based or document-centered work communication in multilingual settings.


Societal impact: This project has created corpora that benefit the research and practice of multilingual teamwork and communication among speakers of various native languages. It has contributed to the diversity in STEM fields by providing research opportunities to multiple undergraduate and graduate students who are women and/or from other underrepresented groups. Additionally, the project has produced educational materials and training modules aimed at equipping the next generation for a linguistically inclusive learning environment and the globalized workforce. The knowledge gained from this project has the potential to refine societal practices in integrating diverse perspectives and ideas into international research collaborations, global educational programs, and multinational business activities.
